Yes, indeed. A well-executed set design can become an integral part of the story and elevate the film's overall quality. In some cases, the set design can become a character in its own right and convey emotions and themes essential to the story.

For example, in the 2017 film "The Shape of Water," the set design played a crucial role in creating the atmosphere of the film. The production design of the laboratory and underwater lair of the creature was a visual feast and helped create a world that felt unique and authentic. The set design was so well-executed that it became an essential part of the story, conveying the emotional journey of the characters and their connections to each other through its design.

Another example is the classic Hitchcock film "Psycho," where the set design of the Bates Motel played a crucial role in conveying the eeriness and tension of the story. The motel's design, with its Gothic and ominous features, helped create an unsettling atmosphere, enhancing the film's suspense and psychological horror.

Overall, a well-executed set design can become an integral part of the storytelling and elevate the film's overall quality, creating a unique and immersive viewing experience.
